Kaizen started in the year 1986.

Kaizen is an art of continuous improvement. It was originally introduced to the west by Masaaki imai in his book Kaizen: The key to Japan's Competitive success in 1986. In the recent times, Kaizen is organized worldwide as an important pillar of an organization's long-term competitive strategy.

This course aims to uncover the basics of Kaizen and important insights to implement Kaizen.

By the end of this short course, you will be able to:

Define Kaizen

Any innovation deteriorates over a period. Hence, it is important to keep making continuous efforts to improve upon the innovation.

It is important to continuously make efforts in routine as well as non routine tasks. Kaizen means helping other teams as well.

Human beings have the potential to make improvements as the right brain which houses the frontal lobe as well as temporal lobe help them to think creatively.However, the challenge is to:The challenge is to:Channelize the creativity of the human brain in the direction the organization desiresCreate a sense of pride in the employeesDocument the numerous small and large improvement efforts

Focussed improvement effort results in quantum improvement in focus areas. To enhance all round performance thousands of small improvements would have been made throughout the system.

Continuous small improvements by everybody in all areas of operation is the most powerful way to reduce variations and defects that are caused by common causes.
